questions.questionText: My customers are saying that Acacia’s 2x600G solution, AC1200, will be available soon. How do I sell against this?  Select ALL that apply.

answers.answerText: The AC1200 is still not planned on competitive platforms until at least 1Q2019, and Acacia has missed their date many times.
Position WaveLogic 5 Extreme as being a better solution for 50GHz gridded networks.
With its strong ramp, WaveLogic Ai provides volume-based savings, allowing it to still be very competitive.
WaveLogic 5 Extreme will be available end of 2019, delivering 800G with a further leapfrog in economics and capacity.
Offer to buy lunch at the most expensive restaurant in the area.

questions.questionText: Which of these statements are true with respect to Ciena’s coherent pluggable strategy? Select ALL that apply

answers.answerText: Ciena will offer 6500-S, 6500-T and Packet Networking devices w/ CFP2-DCO slots in 2019.
Ciena plans to deliver QSFP-DD plugs to address 400ZR applications.
Ciena plans to deliver CFP8 plugs in 1Q2019 for faster time to market.
Ciena plans to deliver 400G in SFP+ pluggables.
Ciena will be offering coherent pluggables for outside plant deployments.
Ciena will be offering CFP2-DCO pluggables mid-2019.

questions.questionText: Cisco, Juniper and Arista are telling your customers they can save “big $” by replacing transport gear with high performance coherent pluggables. How should you respond? Select ALL that apply.

answers.answerText: Agree. Coherent pluggables will be able to address all applications in the near term.
Customers will be able to benefit from the reliable performance of WaveLogic in pluggable form factor with WaveLogic 5 Nano.
Deploying a switch/router anywhere you need transponders means a lot more $$$$.
Provide 90% discount on transport equipment.
The thinking that optical networks rely solely on specific FEC gains and power envelope metrics is greatly oversimplifying transport requirements.

questions.questionText: For which situations should you be positioning 6500 RLS to your customer?  Select ALL that apply.

answers.answerText: Greenfield opportunities starting mid-2019 and later.
When customer needs more than 4 degrees of wavelength switching.
When customer is expanding its 6500 network.
For point-point DCI applications.
For applications requiring compact footprint where 600mm depth is acceptable.
For cost reduction versus 6500 photonics.

questions.questionText: You are competing against Nokia and Infinera in your account, each of which can offer C-band solutions today that can be upgraded to L-band in future. Your customer is leasing fiber, and wants to move forward with INFN or NOK to future-proof their network.  What is your response?  (Choose the SINGLE best option)

answers.answerText: It is cheaper to build another C-band line system than upgrade to C+L.
You can deploy 6500 RLS C-band photonic line today with seamless upgrade to L-band next year.
You can deploy 6500 RLS C-band photonic line today with seamless upgrade to L-band next year.
Describe operational and capacity inefficiencies of NOK/INFN solution; best to wait for RLS C&L.
Propose the Ciena 6500 S-Series C+L submarine hardware for their application.

questions.questionText: Your customer wants you to bid an open line system so that they have the flexibility of deploying any vendor’s coherent transponders on the network. You know that lowest first-in cost is key criteria for this long-time 6500 customer. Select the TWO best options for this scenario.

answers.answerText: State that Ciena does not sell line systems without transponders.
Quote a 6500 line system at slightly higher than typical line system margin, with SW licenses for future capacity additions
Position the 6500 RLS platform at typical line system margins.
Quote a 6500 photonic line system at higher price/margins.
Quote a 6500 line system at your customer’s typical line system margins, with a stipulation that 80% of the transponders are Ciena transponders.
